author: By Ian Austen
title: Beaver Dams Mean No Love Lost for Canada’s Emblematic Animal
description: Blamed for flooded fields, damaged roads and the occasional death, the beaver, which has played a seminal role in Canadian history, is now viewed by many as a problem, not a point of national pride.
content: ALGONQUIN PROVINCIAL PARK, Ontario — The beaver may be one of Canada’s official national symbols, as iconic as the maple leaf, but Canadians have a love-hate relationship with the creature, with the emphasis for many more on the second emotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Mechling
title: Career Coaching Today: Forget the Corporate Ladder and Find Yourself
description: The pandemic created a great reckoning among workers. Here to serve them is a raft of newfangled career coaches.
content: Ana Sarnoski quit her job in the development office at the University of Florida in 2019, shortly after she gave birth to her second daughter. The frequent travel and the expectation that she attend events on nights and weekends were getting to be too much. Once the pandemic hit, she found herself missing the income, and the self-confidence that came with it. She started to wonder what her return to working life would look like given her disinclination to return to a job like her former one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: 3 Officers Used Excessive Force in Arrest of Black Teen, U.S. Says
description: The officers were charged with violating the teenager’s civil rights when they stomped on his head in New Jersey in 2018.
content: A group of police officers approach a wooden shed in a snow-covered patch of South Jersey, yelling, “Get out! Come on out!” to whoever is hiding inside as a police dog whimpers nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Screen Sharing
description: Adam Wagner’s Sunday puzzle commands your full attention.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Adam Wagner made his Times puzzle debut in April, which has led to a most productive and entertaining 2021. He’s a senior copywriter for an ad agency in San Francisco who became interested in constructing a few years ago after he saw some of his former classmates from Brown University appearing in The New York Times. Today’s neat visual trick is exactly the sort of thing that pops into one’s head in the shower or, in Mr. Wagner’s case, in bed. Funny how that happens, and lucky for us that he got out of bed to brainstorm for the rest of the night (and could have filled a far bigger grid, as you will see in the Constructor Notes).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Macy’s Used to Set the Balloons Free, and Other Thanksgiving Day Parade Facts
description: Here is a closer look at the milestones and mishaps involving the helium-filled characters that populate the holiday parade.
content: A hippopotamus soared over the ocean. A cartoon character burst into flames after drifting into a high-tension wire. And a 60-foot cat sent a plane and its two passengers plummeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: A Socialite, a Gardener, a Message in Blood: The Murder That Still Grips France
description: The victim was a socialite. A message in her blood accused the gardener. But a grammatical error raised questions of class and language — and whether he was being framed.
content: PARIS — The wealthy socialite was found dead in the basement of her villa on the Côte d’Azur. The only door was locked from the outside but also barricaded from within. A message, scrawled in the victim’s own blood, seemed to accuse her gardener.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Cold and Snowy Match Leaves Canada’s Soccer Team in an Unexpected Spot
description: The Canadian men’s team, which has not been in the World Cup since 1986, is now leading the regional qualifying competition.
content: The men’s soccer match between Canada and Mexico at Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton this week was peak Canada. At minus 9 Celsius with snow piled around the pitch, Canada won 2-1 and rose to the top of the regional qualifying standings for the World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aisha Sabatini Sloan
title: My Father Was a Black Photojournalist When There Were So Few
description: The writer Aisha Sabatini Sloan and her father, a photojournalist, wrote a book together, “Captioning the Archives.”
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey, Michael Forsythe, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson
title: A Power Struggle Over Cobalt Rattles the Clean Energy Revolution
description: The quest for Congo’s cobalt, which is vital for electric vehicles and the worldwide push against climate change, is caught in an international cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship.
content: KISANFU, Democratic Republic of Congo — Just up a red dirt road, across an expanse of tall, dew-soaked weeds, bulldozers are hollowing out a yawning new canyon that is central to the world’s urgent race against global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Mick Rock, Sought-After Rock Photographer, Dies at 72
description: His images of David Bowie, Lou Reed, Queen and others helped define the 1970s. He was still shooting the stars decades later.
content: Mick Rock, whose striking images of David Bowie, Lou Reed, Debbie Harry, as well as more recent stars like Theophilus London and Snoop Dogg, made him one of rock and pop’s most acclaimed photographers, died on Thursday at a hospital in Staten Island. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Singapore will begin easing its Covid restrictions next week.
description: The Southeast Asian city state is recovering from a recent surge of hospitalizations. An official said its reopening would proceed in a “step-by-step manner.”
content: Singapore said on Saturday that it would begin easing its pandemic restrictions next week, another sign that the city state is recovering from a recent surge of hospitalizations that delayed its reopening plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: The Australian Open will require players to be fully vaccinated.
description: The rule casts doubt on the participation of Novak Djokovic and others.
content: The Australian Open in January will become the first Grand Slam tennis tournament to require that players be fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, a decision that casts doubt on the participation of Novak Djokovic of Serbia, the No. 1-ranked men’s player, who has declined to divulge his vaccination status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Christopher Clarey
title: Videos Said to Be of Peng Shuai Don’t Resolve Questions About Her Safety
description: The editor of a state-run newspaper on Saturday shared clips said to be of the Chinese tennis star on Twitter. But they are unverified, and the head of the WTA called them “insufficient.”
content: Nearly two weeks after people across the world began asking “Where is Peng Shuai?,” two questionable videos surfaced Saturday on social media of a person who appears to be the Chinese tennis star at a restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: With Back Channels to Manchin and Sinema, Pelosi Found a Path to a Deal
description: The House’s approval of a sweeping social policy bill after weeks of fits and starts notched another win for the speaker in a career defined by them.
content: WASHINGTON — On a Wednesday night in September, while President Biden backslapped in the Republican dugout during the annual congressional baseball game, Speaker Nancy Pelosi sat nearby, sober-faced and wagging her finger while speaking into her cellphone, toiling to salvage her party’s top legislative priority as it teetered on the brink of collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Other Traditions Fade, but This One Has Legs
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 20, 2021.
content: “Peanut Butter and Jelly were selected based on their temperament, appearance and, I suspect, vaccination status. Yes, instead of getting basted, these two turkeys are getting boosted.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Kevin McCarthy’s 8-Hour Speech
description: The House Republican leader made a number of false or misleading claims about the social spending bill, President Biden, immigration policy and Teslas.
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California and the minority leader, mounted his case against President Biden’s social spending bill in a record-breaking speech that stretched for more than eight hours from Thursday to Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: A Tool Kit to Help Scientists Find the Ultimate Chickpea
description: A major plant genome sequencing effort may offer a path to breeding more climate-resilient chickpeas, while also revealing clues to the legume’s origins.
content: When you open a can of chickpeas and fish out the nutty, savory little beans, you’re partaking in a history that began around 10,000 years ago. The modern chickpea’s ancestor, a wild Middle Eastern plant that likely had tiny, hard seeds, was cultivated by humans around the same time as wheat and barley, and began to evolve as early farmers selected plants whose seeds were larger and more succulent. Archaeologists have even found what appear to be domesticated chickpeas buried beneath Jericho in the West Bank, so deep that they would have been grown even before the inhabitants of one of history’s longest occupied cities began to make pottery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Protests against Italy’s health pass fizzle.
description: A skimpy turnout for a rally in Rome and the outright failure of one in Milan underscored Italians’ overall acceptance of the country’s Green Pass.
content: Demonstrators gathered in Milan and Rome on Saturday evening to protest Italy’s coronavirus health pass on the 18th consecutive weekend of such rallies. Organizers considered a strong showing necessary to prove that they were a force to be reckoned with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Scams and Slippery Slopes
description: Swindling has become a respectable institution in America. How?
content: I’ve always believed that part of education — especially higher education — is learning to ask better questions about complex topics, knowing you might not have the right answers. In my graduate seminars, one of my favorite ways of prompting students to pursue deeper lines of inquiry is by asking this question: If we take off the table that something is racist, sexist or classist, what else can we say about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Warns Allies of Possible Russian Incursion as Troops Amass Near Ukraine
description: Western intelligence officials are increasingly convinced that the Russian president wants to take control of a larger swath of territory.
content: WASHINGTON — American intelligence officials are warning allies that there is a short window of time to prevent Russia from taking military action in Ukraine, pushing European countries to work with the United States to develop a package of economic and military measures to deter Moscow, according to American and European officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Tries to Convince Arab Allies It Isn’t Abandoning Them
description: The defense secretary faced tough questions about how countries were supposed to deal with a U.S. national security policy that upends itself with each president.
content: MANAMA, Bahrain — The Biden administration is trying to convince its Arab allies that the United States, despite appearances to the contrary, is not fed up with the region and headed for the doors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Co-op Is Snubbing the Menorah in Its Holiday Display. What Can I Do?
description: New York City can review claims of housing discrimination on religious grounds. Co-op boards are expected to act in good faith.
content: Q: My husband and I live in a Midtown East luxury co-op that, for many years, displayed both a large Christmas tree and a menorah in the lobby during the holidays. Last year, after a new board was elected, the menorah was replaced with a smaller one by the elevator, out of sight of visitors. I raised the issue with the board chair, who screamed at me that a menorah is a religious symbol, while a Christmas tree celebrates the spirit of the season. I inquired with the board, but it didn’t change its position. As a Jewish person, I was deeply hurt by these actions and the president’s behavior, which I perceived as discriminatory. What can I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Legends, Often
description: Mary Lou Guizzo makes her return, in collaboration with Jeff Chen.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I am so happy to see these collaborators on a Saturday puzzle, and I was surprised to see that this is Mary Lou Guizzo’s first construction in almost two years, but it has been a very strange almost-two-years. Just last week, I recommended an artful holiday Sunday grid, by Ms. Guizzo and Jeff Chen from 2017, to one of my friends with a prodigious solving appetite who is making their way through back issues. Perhaps you are also lucky enough to have a few unsolved Mary Lou Guizzo puzzles left to discover in the archives (with and without Mr. Chen, who is always such a good partner).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey
title: How Hunter Biden’s Firm Helped Secure Cobalt for the Chinese
description: The president’s son was part owner of a venture involved in the $3.8 billion purchase by a Chinese conglomerate of one of the world’s largest cobalt deposits. The metal is a key ingredient in batteries for electric vehicles.
content: An investment firm where Hunter Biden, the president’s son, was a founding board member helped facilitate a Chinese company’s purchase from an American company of one of the world’s richest cobalt mines, located in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson and Monika Pronczuk
title: What’s Next for the Migrants in Belarus?
description: How President Lukashenko might respond to the crisis he made.
content: The Daily strives to reveal a new idea in every episode. Below, we go deeper on one of those from our show this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg, Coral Murphy Marcos and Kellen Browning
title: Family Unvisited, Travel a No-Go: The Hard Costs of High Gas Prices
description: They hit their highest level since 2014 last month, forcing Americans to rejigger household budgets and forgo leisure activities.
content: A driver in Belleville, N.J., cut his cable and downsized his apartment to save money for gas. A retiree in Vallejo, Calif., said he had stopped driving to go fishing because the miles cost too much in fuel. An auto repairman in Toms River, N.J., doesn’t go to restaurants as often. And an Uber Eats deliveryman said he couldn’t afford frequent visits to his family and friends, some of whom live 60 miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Tabloid ‘Game of Thrones’ in London Could Tilt U.K. Politics
description: The top editor is out at The Daily Mail, widely viewed as the voice of middle-class voters, and the paper’s coverage of Boris Johnson’s government might be softened because of it.
content: LONDON — Geordie Greig was always an odd fit as the editor of The Daily Mail, Britain’s biggest tabloid. Educated at Eton and Oxford; a former editor of the society magazine Tatler; and a friend of the writer V.S. Naipaul and the painter Lucian Freud, Mr. Greig is a suave, aristocratic fellow once described by The Observer as “Britain’s best-connected man.” He also opposed Brexit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Shane Goldmacher
title: G.O.P. Is Energized, but ‘Trump Cancel Culture’ Poses a Threat
description: The former president, tightening his grip on the party as a haphazard kingmaker, threatens Republican incumbents and endorses questionable candidates.
content: PHOENIX — As the country’s Republican governors met this week, there was an unmistakable air of celebration in the conference rooms and cocktail parties marking their annual postelection conference. Gov.-elect Glenn Youngkin of Virginia was swarmed with well wishers and favor seekers who believed his victory in a liberal-leaning state offered the party a road map for next year’s midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Are There So Many Premature Births in America?
description: This shouldn’t happen in a wealthy nation.
content: I was moved this week by Maria Cramer’s story of a baby born at 21 weeks who defied the odds, and now holds the Guinness World Record for the “most premature infant to live to a first birthday.” Curtis Zy-Keith Means was born to Michelle Butler last summer, and even though his twin sister very sadly did not survive, Curtis hung on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Who Has Qualified for the 2022 World Cup?
description: The kickoff to the World Cup in Qatar is a year away, and most of the favorites have already booked their places. The winner, in fact, may already be there.
content: With a year to go, almost half the field for the 2022 World Cup is set. Thirteen countries have already booked their places for the tournament, which opens in Qatar next Nov. 21: some with ease, cruising through qualifying, and some with a touch more drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Knowing What We Don’t Know
description: We need to find out why our neighbors and fellow citizens think the way they do.
content: Paul Finebaum is a very well known person in America. His four-hour simulcast radio show and television show center on college football and, specifically, the Southeastern Conference, and he has an audience in the millions, according to the SEC Network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Rittenhouse Case Highlights the Nation’s Deep Division Over Gun Rights
description: As groups debate the effect of the verdict, the legislative stalemate shows no signs of changing, and weapons on the street grow.
content: Four days before Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted of murder, the judge in his case tossed out a charge: illegal possession of the military-style semiautomatic rifle he used to kill two people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Ooh La La! Le Messy Divorce!
description: The Hundred Years’ War isn’t over. Let’s go for another hundred.
content: WASHINGTON — When I got the invitation from the French ambassador for a black-tie gala called “Améthyste,” I wondered what that name meant. Was it a promotional party for a French jewelry company or maybe a new perfume?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley and A.J. Mast
title: These Americans Are Just Going Around in Circles. It Helps the Climate.
description: An Indiana city has the most roundabouts in the country. They’ve saved lives and reduced injuries from crashes — and lowered carbon emissions.
content: CARMEL, Ind. — It’s getting harder and harder to run a stoplight here, because there are fewer and fewer of them around. Every year, at intersections throughout this thriving city, traffic lights and stop signs have disappeared, replaced with roundabouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Rittenhouse and the Right’s White Vigilante Heroes
description: The great threat is that there are young men out there who watched the verdict and now want to follow Rittenhouse’s lead.
content: Kyle Rittenhouse, the 18-year-old who shot and killed two men and wounded a third last year during protests of the police shooting of Jacob Blake, was found not guilty Friday of all charges by a Wisconsin jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Just a few storms cloud the U.S. travel forecast for a second pandemic Thanksgiving.
description: As families across the United States prepare to gather for Thanksgiving, some for the first time since 2019, there are only a few clouds on the horizon.
content: As families across the United States prepare to gather for Thanksgiving, some for the first time since 2019, there are only a few clouds on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Adding Surprise to Your Reading Life
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Dionne Searcey and Michael Forsythe
title: Race to the Future: What to Know About the Frantic Quest for Cobalt
description: A New York Times investigation examines the global demand for raw materials as the clean energy revolution takes off. This is what we found.
content: The clean energy revolution is replacing oil and gas with a new global force: the minerals and metals needed in electric car batteries, solar panels and other forms of renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: How India’s Farmers, Organized and Well Funded, Faced Down Modi
description: They received foreign and domestic financial support, kept their camps organized and looked for ways to be seen while trying to avoid violence.
content: NEW DELHI — Om Prakash relied on relatives and neighbors to tend his wheat and vegetable fields. He ate food donated by sympathizers at home and abroad. When he felt feverish, he turned to volunteer medical workers huddled, like him, near a noisy overpass for months, through heat and cold and a deadly viral outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford and Rivian no longer plan to work jointly on electric vehicles.
description: Ford remains an investor, but its own E.V. development plans have progressed since the partnership was announced.
content: Ford Motor and Rivian have dropped plans to develop an electric vehicle together, although Ford remains a major investor in the start-up automaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Inside Fentanyl’s Mounting Death Toll: ‘This Is Poison’
description: While a rise in overdose deaths shows the devastating consequences of the opioid’s spread, less is understood about how the drug has proliferated.
content: Dark heroin cut with so much white powdered fentanyl that it’s known on the street as “gray.” Cocaine laced so frequently with fentanyl that club DJs stock anti-overdose medication. Fake prescription pain pills that are in fact all fentanyl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Diminishing Democratic Majority
description: Do Democrats need Trump to save them from an unexpected demographic eclipse?
content: Last weekend I wrote about how the landscape of 2021 is suddenly letting Republicans play politics on “easy” mode, by giving them back the kind of issues that built Ronald Reagan’s majority in the 1970s and 1980 — rising inflation, rising violent crime, a Cold War rivalry (Chinese rather than Russian this time) and backlash against a culturally ascendant but overreaching and self-deceiving left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: F.B.I. Agents Became C.I.A. Operatives in Secret Overseas Prisons
description: Lawyers disclosed the unusual arrangement in evidentiary hearings to prepare for the Sept. 11 trial at Guantánamo Bay.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In the torturous history of the U.S. government’s black sites, the F.B.I. has long been portrayed as acting with a strong moral compass. Its agents, disgusted with the violence they saw at a secret C.I.A. prison in Thailand, walked out, enabling the bureau to later deploy “clean teams” untainted by torture to interrogate the five men accused of conspiring in the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Wildfires in California Killed Thousands of Giant Sequoias
description: The past 15 months have been devastating for the majestic trees, as fires destroyed an estimated 13 to 19 percent of their population, officials said.
content: Three wildfires in California in the past 15 months killed or mortally wounded thousands of mature giant sequoias, accounting for an estimated 13 to 19 percent of the world’s population of the majestic trees, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Thousands in Austria Protest Virus Lockdown and Vaccine Mandate
description: The protests were largely peaceful, but as dusk fell over the Austrian capital, skirmishes broke out between officers and groups of demonstrators.
content: VIENNA — Chanting “freedom” and “resistance,” thousands of Austrians marched through the heart of Vienna on Saturday, united in their anger at their government’s decision to impose a new lockdown and a sweeping nationwide vaccine mandate in an effort to squelch a fresh resurgence of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Hinkel
title: Other legal fallout from the violence in Kenosha is still playing out in the courts.
description: Civil lawsuits accuse the authorities of wrongdoing, both during the turbulence in the city and in the police shooting that sparked it.
content: Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial has shined a searchlight on the violence and destruction that enveloped Kenosha, Wis., for several days in August 2020. But the not-guilty verdicts in the trial will not be the final word on those events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Photographs and Text by Lynsey Addario
title: Covid Vaccine Gets Muted Welcome in Land Awash in Bigger Problems
description: Much of South Sudan is under water from flooding induced by climate change and deforestation. Crops and livestock are lost, hunger and malaria are spreading. With so many worries, coronavirus vaccines are a tough sell.
content: The vaccination campaign team from UNICEF arrived in a small motorboat last month in the flooded village of Wernyol, not far from the capital of South Sudan, and met with elders under a tree on a small patch of dry land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: To Breed or Not to Breed?
description: In a world of pandemic chaos, political strife and climate catastrophe, some would-be parents see the future as too dark to procreate.
content: Before she married her husband, Kiersten Little considered him ideal father material. “We were always under the mentality of, ‘Oh yeah, when you get married, you have kids,” she said. “It was this expected thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Thanksgiving Forecast: Mostly Clear With Minor Travel Delays Possible
description: Weak storms could cause flight delays in some parts of the country but forecasters do not expect any major disruptions.
content: Storms could cause minor delays for people traveling to and from some Southern Plains states and northern New England this Thanksgiving week but nothing that is expected to be widespread or long-lasting, meteorologists said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: One Historic Black Neighborhood’s Stake in the Infrastructure Bill
description: Generations of New Orleans residents have dreamed of the day when the Claiborne Expressway might be removed. President Biden’s $1.2 trillion infrastructure package could eventually make that possible.
content: NEW ORLEANS — In the days after the House passed a $1.2 trillion spending package that promises to pour money into America’s aging infrastructure, several residents of a storied New Orleans neighborhood turned to the highway that divides their streets and pondered a common question: What does this mean for us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Allen Brooks, Victim of a 1910 Lynching, Is Remembered in Dallas
description: A new historical marker commemorates the intersection where a mob paraded Brooks’s body after he was savagely killed while awaiting trial.
content: Allen Brooks, a Dallas handyman accused of raping a little girl, was awaiting the beginning of his trial on March 3, 1910, when a mob stormed the courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Ray Dalio Says, ‘If You Worry, You Don’t Have to Worry’
description: The billionaire founder of the world’s largest hedge fund talked with DealBook about China, inflation and “The Changing World Order,” his new book about empires.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: The Godmother of ‘Plant-Based’ Living
description: Frances Moore Lappé, the author of “Diet for a Small Planet,” which was published 50 years ago and spurred a movement toward vegetarianism, looks back on her legacy.
content: Frances Moore Lappé’s last hamburger was in 1971, the same year she published “Diet for a Small Planet,” her hugely influential book about food and sustainability, which virtually created the publishing category of food politics and turned Ms. Lappé into what she once self-deprecatingly called “the Julia Child of the soybean circuit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren and Lola Fadulu
title: How to Get a Coronavirus Booster Shot in New York City
description: New Yorkers can get coronavirus vaccine booster shots at a number of places, including pop-up vans, churches, local pharmacies and community health clinics.
content: All adults living in New York City are officially eligible to receive coronavirus booster shots, following decisions made Friday by federal regulators to expand eligibility for the shots across the country beyond those who have underlying conditions, live or work in high-risk settings or are over 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Thousands rally against coronavirus restrictions in Australia.
description: Demonstrators gathered in cities around the country to protest vaccine mandates and other rules.
content: Thousands rallied in Melbourne and other Australian cities on Saturday to protest pandemic restrictions and vaccine mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Missouri Detective Is Convicted in Fatal Shooting of Black Man Outside His Home
description: A judge convicted Detective Eric DeValkenaere of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Cameron Lamb outside his home in 2019.
content: A Missouri police detective was found guilty on Friday in the death of a Black man who was fatally shot in 2019 as he sat in a pickup truck outside his home, a remarkable decision given the rarity of convictions in on-duty killings by police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Campoamor
title: ‘When Are You Getting Married?’
description: The holiday season can sometimes lead to uncomfortable quizzing from meddlesome friends and family members about when you and your partner plan to wed. Here’s how to respond.
content: There are a few things that I know will likely happen during holiday family gatherings. My 7-year-old son will show an embarrassingly small amount of gratitude for any gift that isn’t a toy; my 3-year-old son will hurt himself jumping off furniture; and someone from my extended family will ask me when the boys’ father and my partner of eight years plans on proposing. This will force me to say the same thing I say every year: not anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan, Eduardo Medina and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: ‘Accidental Discharge’ of Firearm Prompts Panic at Atlanta Airport
description: Gunfire at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport on Saturday was accidental, officials said, but it led to flight disruptions and a stampede of passengers.
content: ATLANTA — Gunfire at the Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport on Saturday resulted from an “accidental discharge” of a firearm, officials said, but it caused holiday travelers to flee and seek cover as some believed there was a gunman inside one of the terminals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Mitch Smith
title: When it comes to self-defense, the prosecution has a heavier burden.
description: The acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse points to the wide berth given to defendants who say they acted out of fear.
content: For many Americans, the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse on all charges on Friday was a vindication of an innocent, if not heroic, teenager with good intentions. For others, it was a brutal disappointment, further evidence that the courts give white men a pass for their actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Where Is Peng Shuai?
description: The Chinese government must provide answers about the missing tennis star.
content: China’s playbook when confronted with criticism is neither crafty nor subtle: Deny, lie, play dumb, hope it goes away and, when all else fails, strike back ferociously. It’s all happening again in the case of Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star who crossed swords with the state by publicly accusing a former senior Politburo member of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Train the Police to Keep the Peace, Not Turn a Profit
description: A Times investigation sheds light on an unjust practice.
content: Some police departments across the country have embraced the corrupting and unjust practice of raising revenue for their municipalities by pushing officers to write as many traffic tickets as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: When Can the Covid Masks Finally Come Off?
description: Although the end of mask mandates is in sight, restrictions should remain in place through the holidays, experts say.
content: Amid the turmoil of the last two years — a period that included a deadly pandemic, mass layoffs, an ugly presidential election and an attack on the United States Capitol — some of the fiercest political debates in America have been waged over a nearly weightless piece of fabric: the face mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siri Hustvedt
title: Fourth Time Around: The Final Volume of John Richardson’s Biography of Picasso
description: In her review, Siri Hustvedt casts a sharp eye on the most renowned painter of the 20th century.
content: A LIFE OF PICASSO The Minotaur Years, 1933-1943By John Richardson with the collaboration of Ross Finocchio and Delphine Huisinga
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Jay Last, One of the Rebels Who Founded Silicon Valley, Dies at 92
description: He and seven others left the Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory to create their own silicon company, Fairchild Semiconductor, which is now seen as ground zero for the West Coast tech industry.
content: Jay Last, a physicist who helped create the silicon chips that power the world’s computers, and who was among the eight entrepreneurs whose company laid the technical, financial and cultural foundation for Silicon Valley, died on Nov. 11 in Los Angeles. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: How Much Does Biden’s Spending Bill Actually Cost?
description: The climate change and social policy measure that the House just passed includes about $2.2 trillion worth of spending programs and tax cuts. But there are many ways to tally its price tag.
content: House Democrats passed a large bill on Friday that aims to curb climate change, fight poverty and invest in children, workers and families. How large? Probably about $2.2 trillion. But there’s a wide range of other estimates for the price tag, reflecting the difficulties in pinning a true “score” to a plan that has changed a lot over the past weeks and months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Dwayne Johnson Chase Ryan Reynolds in ‘Red Notice’
description: The director Rawson Marshall Thurber narrates a sequence set in a museum.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Eric Lipton
title: How Are Electric Vehicle Batteries Made?
description: The worldwide shift to electric vehicles is critical in the fight against climate change. Here's how the most important part of these cars is made.
content: The worldwide shift to electric vehicles is critical in the fight against climate change. Here's how the most important part of these cars is made.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Lunar Eclipse Seen Around the World
description: The partial eclipse on Thursday night and early Friday morning lasted more than six hours. The last partial eclipse of this duration was in the 1440s.
content: The partial eclipse on Thursday night and early Friday morning lasted more than six hours. The last partial eclipse of this duration was in the 1440s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: ‘Accidental Discharge’ of Firearm Causes Panic at Atlanta Airport
description: Travelers at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport fled and sought cover after a gun discharged in the security screening area. Officials said that the gunfire was accidental and that no one was injured.
content: Travelers at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport fled and sought cover after a gun discharged in the security screening area. Officials said that the gunfire was accidental and that no one was injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Austrians Protest Lockdown and Vaccine Mandate
description: Thousands in Vienna demonstrated against the measures, which includes a nationwide lockdown that the government said would begin on Monday.
content: Thousands in Vienna demonstrated against the measures, which includes a nationwide lockdown that the government said would begin on Monday.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Rioters Clash With the Police in the Netherlands Over Covid Measures
description: The police fired warning shots and used water cannons against hundreds of demonstrators who set fires on the streets of Rotterdam, the Netherlands, in protest of the country’s partial lockdown and its plans to introduce a law allowing businesses to exclude unvaccinated people.
content: The police fired warning shots and used water cannons against hundreds of demonstrators who set fires on the streets of Rotterdam, the Netherlands, in protest of the country’s partial lockdown and its plans to introduce a law allowing businesses to exclude unvaccinated people.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 20, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 20, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about the death of the 36-year-old rapper Young Dolph misstated the make of the car said to belong to him. It was a Corvette, not a Lamborghini.
source.name: The New York Times
